data.text: Contents
Introduction
Airborne contaminants may enter an operating room via the following routes:
Through the supply air
Shed by operating staff (skin fragments with bacteria)
Through surgical activities
Ingress from adjacent spaces
Dilution and exclusion of airborne contaminants is ensured by a well-functioning ventilation system.

The design of the operating theatre should seek to minimise the movement of air from less clean to cleaner areas. Overall ventilation (supply flow rates, air change rates etc.) should give sufficient dilution of airborne bacterial contaminants as per Health Technical Memorandum HTM In addition, the airflow out of cleaner rooms into less clean rooms should prevent backflow of contamination.

Microbial air testing in a conventionally-ventilated theatre is a final check of supply of optimal quality of supply air to the operating theatre and the principles are applied for commissioning and monitoring post-maintenance (where this is indicated).
Scope

The purpose of this document is to ensure that the operating theatre ventilation is optimal in order to prevent airborne microorganisms from entering surgical wounds. This policy reflects national guidance (HTM 03-01).

This policy covers the requirement for microbiological air sampling in a working theatre, commissioning of new theatres and where there has been substantial modifications to the ventilation system or fabric of the theatre.
The areas covered are:
Conventionally-ventilated operating theatres
Ultraclean-ventilated (UCV) operating theatres

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

Ventilation Safety Group remit will be to assess all aspects of ventilation safety and resilience required for the safe development and operation of healthcare premises and is responsible for the review of this policy

Infection Prevention and Control Committee (IPCC) are responsible for providing advice and liaising with the Estates and Facilities department on air sampling and processes. Receive reports on air testing

The Chief Executive has overall responsibility for ensuring that the Trust has the necessary management systems in place to enable the effective implementation of this policy and overall responsibility for the health and safety of staff, patients and visitors.
Theatre Staff

Will ensure a named lead is identified to co-operate with all services, this will include approving the start of the shutdown of systems, ensuring the domestic staff have access to clean, identifying the implications for the service and putting into place mitigation plans and opening the service following the approval of the Estates and Facilities Team.
Domestic Service Manager

Will ensure they liaise with all services, confirm the cleaning of the theatre is organised as required by the facilities team, set up equipment and seal the theatre for the required time, unseal and remove the equipment informing the Estates and Facilities Team that the area is ready for testing.
Estates and Facilities

Estates and Facilities team will carry out or commission PPMs including yearly validations in accordance with an annual plan approved with the theatre committee. They will also carry out emergency unplanned shutdowns to rectify any faults affecting service, as and when they occur. Where necessary they will liaise with IPCT for appropriate actions. They will also co-ordinate all parties involved in managing the shutdown of a system for repair, cleaning, testing and restart of systems.
EFM Project Managers

When there are new works, projects, construction or demolition planned, the Infection Prevention and Control Team must be involved to provide advice and guidance on air movements/changes, methods, procedures and materials to undertake cleaning and decontamination.

There will be consultation between Estates and Facilities and the IPCT regarding the design and layout of new and refurbished wards, departments or areas. Good design will help to limit the spread of infection. Consultation will also take place before commencing any building works that will create dust so that control measures can be planned.
Main procedural document points
Airborne contaminants may enter an operating room via the following routes:
Through the supply air
Shed by operating staff (skin fragments with bacteria)
Through surgical activities
Transferred from adjacent spaces
Dilution of airborne contaminants is ensured by a well-functioning ventilation system

5.2.1 The design of the operating theatre should seek to a) dilute contamination generated in theatre, and b) minimise the movement of air from less clean to cleaner areas. Overall ventilation (supply flow rates, air change rates etc.) should give sufficient dilution of airborne bacterial contaminants as per HTM guidance

5.2.2 Microbiological air testing in an operating theatre is the final check of the supply for optimal quality-air to the theatre and these principles are applied for the commissioning and monitoring post-maintenance (where indicated). It should only be done after all ventilation engineering parameters have been assessed as adequate and reported to the IPCT as such.
Commissioning Conventionally-ventilated theatres

5.3.1  Commissioning is a task for the Estates and Facilities Department, theatre management and the IPCT. Co-operation and co-ordination between them is important. Below is a summary of matters which should be addressed when commissioning conventionally-ventilated theatres.
The Theatre interior should be checked for obvious defects in theatre finishes by the Estates and Facilities, IPCT and theatre management
The air distribution within the theatre and between rooms in the theatre suite should be checked by smoke tracing
The air handling unit supplying the theatre is properly constructed, finished and functioning

Where “setback” (reduction of ventilation rates when theatre is not in use) is in place, there are indications in theatre of its function and there are safeguards against setback operating (i.e. going back to normal ventilation rates), whilst the theatre is in use
The air change rates in theatre and preparation room are satisfactory
Microbiological air sampling results should be satisfactory
Air sampling is required when:
Air sampling is not required after minor maintenance or building work. Sampling is only necessary after work which may affect the quality of volume of air supplied to the operating theatre:
On commissioning (validation) of a new theatre
After work which may affect the way the air is supplied (e.g. new air handling unit) or distributed (modified duct work)
As part of an investigation
Microbiological sampling of operating theatres
An external company will be contacted to do air sampling by Estates and Facilities
Theatre Staff
Following a deep clean and the sealing of the theatres, air sampling will take place. Theatre staff must ensure NO personnel are to enter the theatre until the air sampling has been completed.
Maintenance Staff
For routine AHU shutdowns to carry out PPMs this will be pre-agreed on an annual plan approved with the theatre committee
For unplanned AHU shutdowns inform theatres there is a problem with the AHU system and agree a shutdown programme
Ensure before works commence that Theatres have given approval to the shutdown and confirmed patient care is not at risk
Arrange for any technical assessments to be undertaken re air flows
Confirm to domestic services that works have been completed and cleaning can commence, ensuring theatre staff are informed

The air handling unit MUST BE operating at normal flow rates (i.e. not on setback ventilation) continuously for at least 12  hours prior air sampling being undertaken (This time frame is under review, awaiting next set of guidance)
Ensure technical reports on testing are received from technical advisors and submitted to the Ventilation Safety Group and the IPCC team
Interpretation of air sampling results
The results will be sent to the Estates and Facilities Department. A satisfactory
microbiological sampling result is required to enable a new or refurbished theatre to come into use.

5.8.1  For conventionally ventilated operating theatres, air sampling should demonstrate that aerobic cultures on non-selective media should not exceed  bacterial and/or fungal colony forming units per cubic metre (CFU/m3).
Air sampling in a working theatre

May be indicated where use of theatre may have been possibly implicated in an increase in surgical wound infections. This should not be done as a routine exercise and would only occur following discussions with IPCT.
Ultraclean ventilated theatres

As for conventionally-ventilated theatres, new ultraclean ventilated theatres must be commissioned before being used for the first time or after substantial modifications. Commissioning is a task for both the Estates and Facilities Department and the Infection Prevention and Control team. Co-operation and co-ordination between them is important. The following matters relevant to infection control should be addressed:
The theatre interior should be checked for obvious defects

The airflow between a preparation room used for instrument layup and the theatre is satisfactory and the preparation room has an adequate air change rate as per HTM guidance. There will be different requirements for prep rooms used as sterile pack stores and for layup (though layup under the canopy is optimal)
The air handling unit supplying the theatre is properly constructed, finished and functioning
The air velocities in the ultraclean zone are satisfactory, the terminal HEPA filter is effective and the ultraclean airflow can resist particle penetration from outside
The ultraclean zone resists ingress of air from outside, shown by smoke tests

– this is confirmation of the particle penetration (“entrainment”) test above. Focus here should be on areas where airflows, like those from pressure release dampers from the prep room, may disrupt the downward UCV flow.
Microbiological testing is not necessary
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.
